original: Theravāda Vinayapiṭaka🔽Mahāvagga
analyzed: thera vāda vinaya piṭaka  mahāvagga
translated: The Pāli Canon: Vinaya Piṭaka🔽The Great Division

original: 1. Mahākhandhaka
analyzed: mahākhandhaka
translated: The Great Chapter

original: 1. Bodhikathā
analyzed: bodhi kathā
translated: The Story of the Bodhi Tree

original: Namo tassa Bhagavato Arahato Sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One.

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā uruvelāyaṁ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā uruvelāyam viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhi rukkha mūle paṭhama abhisambuddhaḥ
translated: At that time the Buddha, the Blessed One, was staying in Uruvelā on the bank of the Nerañjarā River, at the root of the Bodhi tree, newly self-awakened.

original: Atha kho bhagavā bodhirukkhamūle sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā bodhi rukkha mūle sattāham eka pallaṅkena nisīdi vimutti sukha paṭisavedī
translated: Then the Blessed One, for seven days, remained in one session, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

original: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā paṭhamaṁ yāmaṁ paṭiccasamuppādaṁ anulomapaṭilomaṁ manasākāsi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā rattiyā paṭhamam yāmam paṭiccasamuppādam anuloma paṭilomam manasā akāsi
translated: Then, in the first watch of the night, the Blessed One directed his mind to the knowledge of the arising and passing away of beings.

original: “Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpapaccayā
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇa viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpa nāma rūpa paccayā
translated: “With ignorance as condition, volitional formations come to be; with volitional formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, name-and-form;

original: saḷāyatanaṁ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā,
analyzed: saḷāyatana saḷāyatana paccayā phassaḥ phassa paccayā vedanā vedanā paccayā taṇhā
translated: with name-and-form as condition, the six sense bases; with the six sense bases as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving;🔽with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging-and-death,

original: taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ
analyzed: taṇhā paccayā upādāna upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ bhava paccayā jāti jāti paccayā jarā maraṇa
translated: and sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair come to be.🔽Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

original: sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
analyzed: soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā sambhavanti
translated: sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress come to be.

original: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.
analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti
translated: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

original: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho,
analyzed: avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho
translated: With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of (volitional) processes. With the cessation of (volitional) processes comes the cessation of consciousness.

original: viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho, nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho, saḷāyatananirodhā
analyzed: viññāṇa nirodhā nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ nāma rūpa nirodhā saḷāyatana nirodho saḷāyatana nirodhā
translated: With the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of mind and bodily form. With the cessation of mind and bodily form comes the cessation of the six sense spheres. With the cessation of the six sense spheres comes the cessation of contact.

original: phassanirodho, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho, vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho, taṇhānirodhā
analyzed: phassa nirodho phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodhaḥ vedanā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhaḥ taṇhā nirodhā
translated: With the cessation of contact comes the cessation of feeling. With the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving. With the cessation of craving comes the cessation of attachment.

original: upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā
analyzed: upādāna nirodhaḥ upādāna nirodhāḥ bhava nirodhaḥ bhava nirodhāḥ jāti nirodhaḥ jāti nirodhā
translated: With the cessation of attachment comes the cessation of continuation. With the cessation of continuation comes the cessation of birth. With the cessation of birth

original: jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

original: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti iti
translated: This is how there is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then the Fortunate One, having understood the significance of it, on that occasion uttered this exalted utterance:

original: “Yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā,
analyzed: yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā
translated: “When the things that lead to the higher consciousness

original: Ātāpino jhāyato brāhmaṇassa;
analyzed: ātāpinaḥ jhāyataḥ brāhmaṇassa
translated: Of the ardent meditating brāhmaṇa become manifest,

original: Athassa kaṅkhā vapayanti sabbā,
analyzed: athassa kaṅkhāḥ vapayanti sabbā
translated: All his doubts are dispelled,

original: Yato pajānāti sahetudhamman”ti.
analyzed: yatas pajānāti sa hetu dhammanti
translated: When he understands the Dhamma with its practice and its goal.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā majjhimaṁ yāmaṁ paṭiccasamuppādaṁ anulomapaṭilomaṁ manasākāsi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā rattiyāḥ majjhimam yāmam paṭiccasamuppādam anuloma paṭilomam manasā akāsi
translated: Then, in the middle part of the night, the Buddha reflected on the dependent origination in forward and reverse order:

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti pe

analyzed: nirodhaḥ ha iti

analyzed: atha kho bhagavā rattiyā pacchimam yāmam paṭiccasamuppādam anuloma paṭilomam manasā akāsi

analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇa viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam pe
translated: “With ignorance as condition, volitional formations come to be; with volitional formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, name-and-form; …

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti pe

analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

analyzed: yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā

translated: to the brahmin who is ardent and meditating,

original: Vidhūpayaṁ tiṭṭhati mārasenaṁ,
analyzed: vidhūpayam tiṭṭhati mā arasena
translated: he stands dispelling the army of Death,

original: Sūriyova obhāsayamantalikkhan”ti.
analyzed: sūriyā uva obhāsayam antalikkhanti
translated: like the sun illuminating the sky.”

analyzed: bodhi kathā niṭṭhitā

original: 2. Ajapālakathā🔽Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā bodhirukkhamūlā
analyzed: ajapāla kathā  atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā bodhi rukkha mūlā
translated: . The account of the Goatherd’s Banyan Tree

original: yena ajapālanigrodho tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā ajapālanigrodhamūle sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena
analyzed: yena ajapāla nigrodhaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā ajapāla nigrodha mūle sattāham eka pallaṅkena
translated: Then, after seven days, the Buddha came out of that stillness. He went from the root of the Bodhi tree to the Goatherd’s Banyan Tree. There he sat cross-legged for seven days,

original: nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.🔽Atha kho aññataro huṁhuṅkajātiko brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: nisīdi vimutti sukha paṭisavedī  atha kho aññataraḥ huhuṅka jātikaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami
translated: experiencing the bliss of freedom.🔽A certain brahmin who was a chatterbox went up to the Buddha,🔽exchanged greetings with him,

original: Upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi 🔽sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi
translated: and stood to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: eka mantam ṭhitaḥ kho saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: As he was standing there, he said to the Buddha,

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo hoti, katame ca pana brāhmaṇakaraṇā dhammā”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bho gotama brāhmaṇaḥ hoti katame ca pana brāhmaṇa karaṇāḥ dhammā ti
translated: “Master Gotama, in what way is one a brahmin? And what are the qualities that make one a brahmin?”

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

original: “Yo brāhmaṇo bāhitapāpadhammo,🔽Nihuṁhuṅko nikkasāvo yatatto;
analyzed: yaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ  nihuhuṅkaḥ nikkasāvaḥ yatattaḥ
translated: “The one who has expelled bad qualities,🔽who is not a humbug, is free of defilements, and is well concentrated,

original: Vedantagū vusitabrahmacariyo,
analyzed: vedantagū
translated: who has attained the end, and has lived the spiritual life,

original: Dhammena so brahmavādaṁ vadeyya;
analyzed: dhammena saḥ brahma vādam vadeyya
translated: he may rightly call himself a brahmin.

original: Yassussadā natthi kuhiñci loke”ti.
analyzed: na atthi kuhiñci loke ti
translated: He has no swelling anywhere in the world.”

original: Ajapālakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ajapāla kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The account of Ajapāla is finished.

original: 3. Mucalindakathā🔽Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā ajapālanigrodhamūlā
analyzed: mucalinda kathā  atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā ajapāla nigrodha mūlā
translated: The account of Mucalinda

original: yena mucalindo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā mucalindamūle sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena🔽nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.
analyzed: yena mucalindaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā mucalinda mūle eka pallaṅkena  nisīdi vimutti sukha paṭisavedī
translated: Then, with the passing of seven days, after emerging from that concentration, the Buddha went from the root of the Ajapāla banyan tree to the Mucalinda. He then sat cross-legged for seven days experiencing the bliss of freedom.

original: Tena kho pana samayena mahā akālamegho udapādi, sattāhavaddalikā sītavātaduddinī.
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena mahā akāla meghaḥ udapādi satta aha vaddalikā sīta vāta duddinī
translated: At that time a great out-of-season storm arose, with cold winds and rain.

original: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā sakabhavanā nikkhamitvā bhagavato kāyaṁ sattakkhattuṁ bhogehi parikkhipitvā uparimuddhani mahantaṁ phaṇaṁ karitvā aṭṭhāsi—
analyzed: atha kho mucalindaḥ nāga rājā saka bhavanā nikkhamitvā bhagavato kāyam satta kkhattum bhogehi parikkhipitvā upari muddhani mahantam phaṇam karitvā aṭṭhāsi
translated: Then Mucalinda, the king of the nāgas, came out of his dwelling, coiled his coils around the Buddha’s body seven times, and spread his large hood above his head,

original: “mā bhagavantaṁ sītaṁ, mā bhagavantaṁ uṇhaṁ, mā bhagavantaṁ ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphasso”ti.
analyzed: mā bhagavantam sīta mā bhagavantam uṇha mā bhagavantam ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassa uti
translated: thinking, “May the Buddha not be cold, may he not be hot, may he not be affected by gadflies, mosquitoes, wind, the heat, and serpents.”🔽Then, when it had rained for seven days,

original: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā sattāhassa accayena viddhaṁ vigatavalāhakaṁ devaṁ viditvā
analyzed: atha kho mucalindaḥ nāga rājā satta ahassa accayena viddham vigata valāhakam devam viditvā
translated: Mucalinda, the king of the nāgas, knew that the sky was free of clouds.

original: bhagavato kāyā bhoge viniveṭhetvā sakavaṇṇaṁ paṭisaṁharitvā māṇavakavaṇṇaṁ abhinimminitvā
analyzed: bhagavato kāyāḥ bhoge viniveṭhetvā sa ka vaṇṇam paṭisaharitvā māṇavaka vaṇṇam abhinimminitvā
translated: He unraveled his coils from the Buddha’s body, withdrew his own form, and appeared in the form of a young brahmin.

original: bhagavato purato aṭṭhāsi pañjaliko bhagavantaṁ namassamāno.
analyzed: bhagavato puratas aṭṭhāsi pañjalikaḥ bhagavantam namassamānaḥ
translated: He then stood in front of the Buddha with palms together, paying homage to the Buddha.

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Knowing that this was the right time, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

original: “Sukho viveko tuṭṭhassa,
analyzed: sukhaḥ vivekaḥ tuṭṭhassa
translated: “For one who is content, seclusion is bliss,

original: sutadhammassa passato;
analyzed: suta dhammassa passataḥ
translated: for one who sees the truth through learning.

original: Abyāpajjaṁ sukhaṁ loke,
analyzed: a byāpajjam sukham loke
translated: In this world, the bliss of non-violence,

original: pāṇabhūtesu saṁyamo.🔽Sukhā virāgatā loke,
analyzed: pāṇabhūtesu sayamaḥ  sukhā virāga tā loke
translated: the restraint of the body,🔽The bliss of dispassion in the world,

original: kāmānaṁ samatikkamo;
analyzed: kāmānam samatikkamaḥ
translated: the transcending of sensual pleasures,

original: Asmimānassa yo vinayo,
analyzed: asmimānassa yaḥ vinayaḥ
translated: The complete restraint of conceit:

original: etaṁ ve paramaṁ sukhan”ti.
analyzed: etam ve paramam sukhanti
translated: That is the highest happiness.”

original: Mucalindakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mucalinda kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The account of Mucalinda is finished.

original: 4. Rājāyatanakathā🔽Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā mucalindamūlā yena🔽rājāyatanaṁ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājāyatanamūle sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi
analyzed: rāja āyatana kathā  atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā mucalinda mūlā yena  rājāyatanam tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā rājāyatana mūle sattāham eka pallaṅkena nisīdi
translated: The account with the royal sage

original: vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.
analyzed: vimutti sukha paṭisavedī
translated: Then, with the passing of seven days, the Buddha came out of that stillness. He went from the root of Mucalinda’s tree to the royal sage’s footpad. He then sat cross-legged for seven days experiencing the bliss of freedom.

original: Tena kho pana samayena tapussa bhallikā vāṇijā ukkalā taṁ desaṁ addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena tapussa bhallikāḥ vāṇijāḥ ukkalāḥ tam desam addhāna magga ppaṭipannāḥ honti
translated: At that time the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika were traveling on the main road to that place.

original: Atha kho tapussabhallikānaṁ vāṇijānaṁ ñātisālohitā devatā tapussabhallike vāṇije etadavoca—
analyzed: atha kho tapussabhallikānam vāṇijānam ñātisālohitā devatā tapussabhallike vāṇije etat avoca
translated: Then a deity related to the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika said to them,

original: “ayaṁ, mārisā, bhagavā rājāyatanamūle viharati paṭhamābhisambuddho;
analyzed: mārisā bhagavā rājāyatana mūle viharati paṭhama abhisambuddhaḥ
translated: “Sirs, the Buddha, who has just become fully enlightened, is staying at the foot of the royal sage’s tree.

original: gacchatha taṁ bhagavantaṁ manthena ca madhupiṇḍikāya ca patimānetha;
analyzed: gacchatha tam bhagavantam manthena ca madhupiṇḍikāya ca patim ānetha
translated: Go and offer him rice porridge and pastries.

original: taṁ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
analyzed: tat vaḥ bhavissati dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati
translated: That will be for your benefit and happiness for a long time.”

original: Atha kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
analyzed: atha kho tapussa bhallikāḥ vāṇijāḥ manthañca madhu piṇḍikañca ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhasu
translated: The Tapussa and Bhallika took the honey and the honey-balls and went to the Buddha. They bowed, sat down,

original: Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: ekamantam ṭhitā kho tapussabhallikāḥ vāṇijāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: and said,

original: “paṭiggaṇhātu no, bhante, bhagavā manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca, yaṁ amhākaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
analyzed: paṭiggaṇhātu naḥ bhante bhagavā manthañca madhu piṇḍikañca yam amhākam assa dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati
translated: “Sir, please accept the honey and the honey-balls. It will be for our benefit and happiness for a long time.”

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi—
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: The Buddha thought,

original: “na kho tathāgatā hatthesu paṭiggaṇhanti.
analyzed: na kho tathāgatāḥ hatthesu paṭiggaṇhanti
translated: “The Buddhas don’t receive things in their hands.

original: Kimhi nu kho ahaṁ paṭiggaṇheyyaṁ manthañca madhupiṇḍikañcā”ti?
analyzed: kimhi nu kho aham paṭiggaṇheyyam mantham ca madhu piṇḍikañca ati
translated: What should I use to receive the honey and the honey-balls?”

original: Atha kho cattāro mahārājāno bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya catuddisā cattāro selamaye patte bhagavato upanāmesuṁ—
analyzed: atha kho cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ bhagavato cetasā cetaḥ upari vitakka maññāya catuddisā cattāraḥ sela maye patte bhagavataḥ upanāmesu
translated: The four great kings read the Buddha’s mind. They brought four jeweled bowls from the four directions and said,

original: “idha, bhante, bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu manthañca madhupiṇḍikañcā”ti.
analyzed: idha bhante bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu manthañca madhu piṇḍikañca ati
translated: “Sir, please receive the honey and the honey-balls in these.”

original: Paṭiggahesi bhagavā paccagghe selamaye patte manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca, paṭiggahetvā paribhuñji.
analyzed: paṭiggahesi bhagavā paccagghe sela maye patte manthañca madhu piṇḍikañca paṭiggahetvā paribhuñji
translated: The Buddha accepted the silver bowl and the milk-rice and honey balls, and he ate them.

original: Atha kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā bhagavantaṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ viditvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: atha kho tapussabhallikāḥ vāṇijāḥ bhagavantam onīta patta pāṇim viditvā bhagavataḥ pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: Then the traders Tapussa and Bhallika, knowing that the Buddha had finished his meal, sat down to one side. They bowed, put their palms together, and said,

original: “ete mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca, upāsake no bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṁ gate”ti.
analyzed: ete bhante bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāma dhammañca upāsake naḥ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇam gatā iti
translated: “Sir, we go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks. Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

original: Te ca loke paṭhamaṁ upāsakā ahesuṁ dvevācikā.
analyzed: te ca loke paṭhamam upāsakāḥ ahesum
translated: They were the first lay followers in the world.

original: Rājāyatanakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rāja āyatana kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The account of Rājagaha is finished.

original: 5. Brahmayācanakathā
analyzed: brahma yācana kathā
translated: The request of Brahmā

original: Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rājāyatanamūlā yena ajapālanigrodho tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rāja āyatana mūlā yena ajapāla nigrodho tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then, after seven days, the Buddha came out of that stillness and went from the root of the Rājagaha shrine to the goatherd’s banyan tree.

original: Tatra sudaṁ bhagavā ajapālanigrodhamūle viharati.
analyzed: tatra sudam bhagavān ajapāla nigrodha mūle viharati
translated: He stayed in a wilderness thicket near that tree.

original: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavataḥ rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evam cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, while reflecting in private, he thought,

original: “adhigato kho myāyaṁ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.
analyzed: adhigataḥ kho myā ayam dhammaḥ gambhīraḥ duddasaḥ duranubodhaḥ santaḥ paṇītaḥ a takka avacaraḥ nipuṇaḥ paṇḍita vedanīyo
translated: “This truth I have discovered is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, profound, understandable (only) to the wise.

original: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṁ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.
analyzed: ālaya rāmā khalu pana ayam pajā ālaya ratā ālaya sammuditā
translated: But this generation delights in desire, is devoted to desire, gladdened by desire,

original: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṁ idaṁ ṭhānaṁ yadidaṁ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo;
analyzed: ālaya rāmāya kho pana pajāya ālaya ratāya ālaya sammuditāya duddasam idam ṭhānam yat idam idappaccaya tā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: and for a generation delighting in desire, devoted to desire, gladdened by desire this thing is hard to see, that is to say: conditionality and conditional origination.

original: idampi kho ṭhānaṁ sududdasaṁ yadidaṁ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṁ.
analyzed: idam api kho ṭhānam su duddasam yat idam sabba saṅkhāra samatho sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo taṇhā kkhayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ nibbāna
translated: This thing also is very hard to see, that is to say: the stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all attachments, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna.

original: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṁ deseyyaṁ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṁ, so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana dhammam deseyya pare ca me naḥ ājāneyyu saḥ mamassa kilamatho sā mamassa vihesā ati
translated: If I were to teach the Truth, others would not understand me, and that would be wearying and troublesome for me.”

original: Apissu bhagavantaṁ imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṁsu pubbe assutapubbā—
analyzed: bhagavantam imāḥ anacchariyāḥ gāthāyaḥ pubbe a ssuta pubbā
translated: And these verses, unheard of before, occurred to the Fortunate One:

original: “Kicchena me adhigataṁ,
analyzed: kicchena me adhigata
translated: “What I attained with difficulty,

original: halaṁ dāni pakāsituṁ;
analyzed: halam dāni pakāsitu
translated: it is not easy to make it known to others,🔽This Truth is not easily understood

original: Rāgadosaparetehi,🔽nāyaṁ dhammo susambudho.
analyzed: rāga dosa paretā ihi  na ayam dhammo su sambudho

original: Paṭisotagāmiṁ nipuṇaṁ,

translated: It goes against the stream, it is profound,

original: gambhīraṁ duddasaṁ aṇuṁ;
analyzed: gambhīram duddasam aṇu
translated: It’s profound and hard to see, subtle, and beyond the intellect.

original: Rāgarattā na dakkhanti,
analyzed: rāga rattāḥ na dakkhanti
translated: Those infatuated with sensual pleasures won’t see it,

original: tamokhandhena āvuṭā”ti.

original: “nassati vata bho loko, vinassati vata bho loko, yatra hi nāma tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa appossukkatāya cittaṁ namati, no dhammadesanāyā”ti.

original: Atha kho brahmā sahampati—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.

translated: And just as quickly as an athlete can extend their flexed arm or flex their extended arm, Brahmā Sahampati disappeared from the Brahmā realm and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

original: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṁ pathaviyaṁ nihantvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca—

translated: Then Brahmā Sahampati, arranging his upper robe on one shoulder, extending his hands in reverential salutation towards the Blessed One, said to him:

analyzed: desetu bhante bhagavā dhamma desetu sugataḥ dhamma
translated: “Venerable sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Sublime One teach the Dhamma!

original: Sele yathā pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhito,

original: udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakaṁ accuggamma ṭhitāni anupalittāni udakena;🔽evamevaṁ bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṁ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe

translated: In a world that has become blind,

original: Āhañchaṁ amatadundubhin”ti.
analyzed: āhan śam amatadundubhinti
translated: I will beat the drum of the deathless.”

original: “Yathā kho tvaṁ, āvuso, paṭijānāsi, arahasi anantajino”ti.🔽“Mādisā ve jinā honti,
analyzed: yathā kho tvam āvuso paṭijānāsi a rahasi  mādisā ve jināḥ honti
translated: “If you claim to be a Worthy One, an all-conqueror.”

original: ye pattā āsavakkhayaṁ;
analyzed: ye pattāḥ āsava kkhaya
translated: “Those who have attained the destruction of defilements🔽are indeed conquerors like me.

original: Jitā me pāpakā dhammā,
analyzed: jitāḥ me pāpakāḥ dhammā
translated: I have conquered bad qualities,

original: tasmāhamupaka jino”ti.
analyzed: tasmāt aham upaka jinoti
translated: so I am a conqueror, Upaka.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, upako ājīvako hupeyyapāvusoti vatvā sīsaṁ okampetvā ummaggaṁ gahetvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: evam vutte upakaḥ ājīvakaḥ hupeyya pāvuso ti vatvā sīsam okampetvā ummaggam gahetvā pakkāmi
translated: When this was said, Upaka said, “May it be so, friend,” and he turned back and went the other way.

original: Atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena bārāṇasī isipatanaṁ migadāyo, yena pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikam caramānaḥ yena bārāṇasī isipatanam migadāyaḥ yena pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then, wandering by stages, the Blessed One eventually arrived at Bārāṇasī, at the Deer Park in Isipatana, and went to where the group of five monks were staying.

original: Addasaṁsu kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ;
analyzed: addasasu kho pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavantam dūratas vas āgacchanta
translated: The group of five monks saw the Blessed One coming in the distance

original: disvāna aññamaññaṁ katikaṁ saṇṭhapesuṁ—
analyzed: disvāna aññam aññam katikam saṇṭhapesu
translated: and, in order to block his way, they reached an agreement:

original: “ayaṁ, āvuso, samaṇo gotamo āgacchati, bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya.
analyzed: ayaḥ āvuso samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ āgacchati bāhullikaḥ padhāna vibbhantaḥ āvattaḥ bāhullāya
translated: “Venerable Gotama is coming, leading a life of luxury, straying from his exertion, and reverting to luxury.

original: So neva abhivādetabbo, na paccuṭṭhātabbo, nāssa pattacīvaraṁ paṭiggahetabbaṁ;
analyzed: saḥ na iva abhivādetabbaḥ na paccuṭṭhātabbaḥ na assa patta cīvaram
translated: He shouldn’t be bowed down to, nor should he be stood up for. His bowl and robe shouldn’t be received,

original: api ca kho āsanaṁ ṭhapetabbaṁ, sace so ākaṅkhissati nisīdissatī”ti.
analyzed: api ca kho āsanam sace saḥ ākaṅkhissati nisīdissati iti
translated: but a seat may be offered to him in case he wants to sit down.”

original: Yathā yathā kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū upasaṅkamati tathā tathā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū nāsakkhiṁsu sakāya katikāya saṇṭhātuṁ.
analyzed: yathā yathā kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū upasaṅkamati tathā tathā pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū na asakkhisu sakāya katikāya saṇṭhātu
translated: But the more the Blessed One approached the group of five monks, the less able they were to keep to their agreement.

original: Asaṇṭhahantā bhagavantaṁ paccuggantvā eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṁ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṁ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṁ, eko pādapīṭhaṁ, eko pādakaṭhalikaṁ upanikkhipi.🔽Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane;
analyzed: a saṇṭhahantā bhagavantam paccuggantvā ekaḥ bhagavataḥ patta cīvaram paṭiggahesi ekaḥ āsanam paññapesi ekaḥ pāda udake ekaḥ pāda pīṭhe ekaḥ pāda kaṭhalikam upanikkhipi  nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane
translated: They went out to meet the Buddha, one taking his bowl and robe, one preparing a seat, one putting out a foot stool, one putting out a foot scraper, and one taking his water pot.🔽The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat

original: nisajja kho bhagavā pāde pakkhālesi.
analyzed: nisajja kho bhagavā pāde pakkhālesi
translated: and washed his feet.

original: Apissu bhagavantaṁ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaranti.
analyzed: bhagavantam nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaranti
translated: They addressed him by name and as “friend.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—
analyzed: evam vutte bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said to them,

original: “mā, bhikkhave, tathāgataṁ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaratha.
analyzed: mā bhikkhave tathāgatam nāmena ca āvuso vādena ca samudācaratha
translated: “Don’t address the Buddha by name and as ‘friend.’

original: Arahaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sammāsambuddho, odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṁ, amatamadhigataṁ, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
analyzed: araha bhikkhave tathāgataḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ bhikkhave sota amatam adhigata aham anusāsāmi aham dhammaṃ desemi
translated: The Buddha is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. Listen, monks, the deathless has been attained. I will instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.🔽Practicing in this way,

original: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—
analyzed: yathā anusiṭṭham tathā paṭipajjamānāḥ nacirassa eva
translated: you will soon realize

original: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—
analyzed: yassa atthāya kula puttā sammat eva agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajanti tat anuttara
translated: the supreme end of the spiritual life for which sons of good family rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

original: brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya pariyosānam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatha ati
translated: and you will live having known, experienced, and attained it yourself in this very life.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: evam vutte pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the group of five monks replied to the Buddha,

original: “tāyapi kho tvaṁ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya, tāya paṭipadāya, tāya dukkarakārikāya nevajjhagā
analyzed: tāya api kho tvam āvuso gotamaḥ iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkara kārikāya
translated: “Friend Gotama, you haven’t attained any higher state of awareness or a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of a noble one.

original: uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ, kiṁ pana tvaṁ etarahi, bāhulliko
analyzed: uttari manussa dhammāḥ alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesa kim pana tvam etarahi bāhullikaḥ
translated: You’re just working hard,

original: padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya, adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan”ti?
analyzed: padhāna vibbhantaḥ āvattaḥ bāhullāya adhigamissasi uttari manussa dhammā alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesanti
translated: and you’ve turned back to the lower life.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—
analyzed: evam vutte bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the Buddha replied to the group of five monks,

original: “na, bhikkhave, tathāgato bāhulliko, na padhānavibbhanto, na āvatto bāhullāya;
analyzed: na bhikkhave tathāgataḥ bāhullikaḥ na padhāna vibbhantaḥ na āvattaḥ bāhullāya
translated: “Monks, I’m not working hard, nor have I turned back to the lower life.

original: arahaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sammāsambuddho.
analyzed: araha bhikkhave tathāgataḥ sammāsambuddho
translated: I am a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

original: Odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṁ, amatamadhigataṁ ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
analyzed: odahatha bhikkhave sota amatam adhigatam aham anusāsāmi aham dhammaṃ desemi
translated: Listen, monks, I will teach you the Dhamma.

original: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—🔽yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—
analyzed: yathā anusiṭṭham tathā paṭipajjamānāḥ nacirassa eva  yassa atthāya kula puttā sammat eva agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajanti tat anuttara
translated: If you practice in the way you’ve been taught,🔽before long you’ll realize the supreme end of the spiritual life for which sons of good family rightly go forth from the home to the homeless life,

original: brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.🔽Dutiyampi kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ …pe….
analyzed: brahmacariya pariyosānam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatha ati  dutiyam pi kho pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocum pe
translated: and you’ll enter and dwell in it.”🔽For a second time the group of five monks said to the Buddha,

original: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca …pe….
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etat avoca pe
translated: and for a second time the Buddha said to them,

original: Tatiyampi kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—🔽“tāyapi kho tvaṁ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya, tāya paṭipadāya, tāya dukkarakārikāya nevajjhagā
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ  tāya api kho tvam āvuso gotamaḥ iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkara kārikāya
translated: For a third time the group of five monks said to the Buddha,

original: uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ, kiṁ pana tvaṁ etarahi, bāhulliko
analyzed: uttari manussa dhammāḥ alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesa kim pana tvam etarahi bāhullikaḥ
translated: “In that way of living, that practice, that performance of austerities, you didn’t arrive at any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.🔽So how could you, now that you’ve given up that practice and returned to luxury,

original: padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya, adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan”ti?
analyzed: padhāna vibbhantaḥ āvattaḥ bāhullāya adhigamissasi uttari manussa dhammā alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesanti
translated: arrive at any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones?”

original: Evaṁ vutte bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—
analyzed: evam vutte bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When he had finished, he said to the five monks,

original: “abhijānātha me no tumhe, bhikkhave, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ pabhāvitametan”ti?
analyzed: abhijānātha me no tumhe bhikkhave itas pubbe evarūpam pabhāvitam etat ti
translated: “Monks, have I ever said this to you before?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, sir.”

original: “Arahaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sammāsambuddho, odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṁ, amatamadhigataṁ ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
analyzed: araha bhikkhave tathāgataḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ odahatha bhikkhave sota amatam adhigatam aham anusāsāmi aham dhammaṃ desemi
translated: “I am a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. Listen and pay close attention, I will instruct you.

original: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—🔽yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—
analyzed: yathā anusiṭṭham tathā paṭipajjamānāḥ nacirassa eva  yassa atthāya kula puttā sammat eva agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajanti tat anuttara
translated: If you practice in line with what I say, you will soon realize—🔽for the benefit and happiness of both—

original: brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya pariyosānam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatha ati
translated: the supreme end of the spiritual life for which clansmen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

original: Asakkhi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū saññāpetuṁ.
analyzed: asakkhi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū saññāpetu
translated: But the Buddha was unable to convince the group of five.

original: Atha kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ sussūsiṁsu, sotaṁ odahiṁsu, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpesuṁ.
analyzed: atha kho pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavantam sussūsisu sotam odahisu aññā cittam upaṭṭhāpesu
translated: So they listened to what he said, paid attention, and focused their minds.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: The Buddha said to them,

original: “Dveme, bhikkhave, antā pabbajitena na sevitabbā.
analyzed: dve me bhikkhave antāḥ pabbajitena na sevitabbā
translated: “Monks, there are these two extremes that should not be cultivated by one who has gone forth.

original: Katame dve?
analyzed: katame dve
translated: What two?

original: Yo cāyaṁ kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, yo cāyaṁ attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṁhito.
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam kāmesu kāma sukhallika anuyogaḥ hīnaḥ gammaḥ pothujjanikaḥ anariyaḥ anattha sahitaḥ yaḥ ca ayam atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ dukkhaḥ anariyaḥ anattha sahitaḥ
translated: There is the pursuit of sensual happiness in sense pleasures, which is low, vulgar, the way of worldlings, ignoble, unbeneficial; and there is the pursuit of self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, unbeneficial.

original: Ete kho, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ete kho bhikkhave ubho ante an upagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati
translated: Without veering towards either of these extremes, the One Attuned to Reality awakened to the middle way, which produces vision, which produces knowledge, which leads to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbāna.

original: Katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati?🔽Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: katamā ca sā bhikkhave majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati  ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: And what, monks, is that middle way awakened to by the One Attuned to Reality, which produces vision, which produces knowledge, which leads to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbāna?

original: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappo sammā vācā sammā kammanto sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi
translated: It is just this noble eightfold path, that is, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

original: Ayaṁ kho sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam kho sā bhikkhave majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati
translated: This is the middle way awakened to by the Tathāgata—which produces vision, produces knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, self-awakening, and unbinding.

original: Idaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ.
analyzed: idam kho pana bhikkhave dukkham ariya sacca
translated: “And this, monks, is the noble truth of stress:

original: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, byādhipi dukkho, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho, piyehi vippayogo dukkho, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.
analyzed: jāti pi dukkhā jarā api dukkhā byādhi pi dukkhaḥ maraṇam pi dukkha appiyehi sampayogaḥ dukkhaḥ piyehi vippayogaḥ dukkhaḥ yam piccham na labhati tam pi dukkha
translated: Birth is stressful, aging is stressful, death is stressful; sorrow, lamentation, pain, distress, & despair are stressful; association with the unbeloved is stressful, separation from the loved is stressful, not getting what is wanted is stressful.

original: Saṅkhittena, pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
analyzed: saṅkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā
translated: In short, the five clinging-aggregates are stressful.

original: Idaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ—🔽yāyaṁ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: idam kho pana bhikkhave dukkha samudayam ariya sat ca  yā ayam taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandī rāga sahagatā tatra tatra abhinandinī
translated: “And this, monks, is the noble truth of the origination of stress:

original: kāmataṇhā, bhavataṇhā, vibhavataṇhā.
analyzed: kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā
translated: the craving that makes for further becoming—accompanied by passion & delight, relishing now here & now there—i.e., craving for sensuality, craving for becoming, craving for non-becoming.

original: Idaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ—
analyzed: idam kho pana bhikkhave dukkha nirodham ariya sacca
translated: “And this, monks, is the noble truth of the cessation of stress:

original: yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho, cāgo, paṭinissaggo, mutti, anālayo.
analyzed: yaḥ tassāya eva taṇhāya asesa virāga nirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo
translated: the remainderless fading & cessation, renunciation, relinquishment, release, & letting go of that very craving.

original: Idaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ—🔽ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: idam kho pana bhikkhave dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya sacca  ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: “And this, monks, is the noble truth of the practice leading to the end of suffering:

original: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.🔽Idaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappo sammā vācā sammā kammanto sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi  idam dukkham ariya saccanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: It is this noble eightfold path itself, that is, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.🔽‘This is the noble truth of suffering’: such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, awareness, and light that arose in me regarding things I had not previously heard.

original: Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pariññeyyanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: tam kho panidam dukkham ariya saccam pariññeyyanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: ‘This noble truth of suffering should be fully understood’: such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, awareness, and light that arose in me regarding things I had not previously heard.

original: Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pariññātanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.🔽Idaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.🔽Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pahātabbanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: tam kho panidam dukkham ariya saccam pariññātanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi  idam dukkha samudayam ariya saccanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi  tam kho panidam dukkha samudayam ariya saccam pahātabbanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: ‘This noble truth of suffering has been fully understood’ — such was my knowledge and insight, and so this has been said.🔽‘This is the noble truth of the arising of suffering’ — such was my knowledge and insight, and so this has been said.🔽‘This noble truth of the arising of suffering should be given up’ — such was my knowledge and insight, and so this has been said.

original: Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pahīnanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: tam kho panidam dukkha samudayam ariya saccam pahīnam ti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: ‘This noble truth of the arising of suffering has been given up’ — such was my knowledge and insight, and so this has been said.

original: Idaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.🔽Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ sacchikātabbanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.🔽Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ sacchikatanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: idam dukkha nirodham ariya saccanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi  tam kho panidam dukkha nirodham ariya saccam sacchikātabbanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi  tam kho panidam dukkha nirodham ariya saccam sacchikatanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering’: insight arose, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, light arose.🔽‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized’: insight arose, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, light arose.🔽‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering has been realized’: insight arose, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, light arose.

original: Idaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: idam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya saccanti me bhikkhave pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: ‘This is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering’: insight arose, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, light arose.

original: Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ bhāvetabbanti me, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tam kho panidam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya saccam bhāvetabbanti me bhikkhave
translated: ‘This is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering’ should be developed’:

original: pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā
analyzed: pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā
translated: knowledge and vision arose, understanding arose,

original: udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: penetration arose, light arose.

original: Taṁ kho panidaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ bhāvitanti me, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tam kho panidam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya saccam bhāvitanti me bhikkhave
translated: ‘This is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering’ has been developed’:

original: pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṁ udapādi, ñāṇaṁ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā
analyzed: pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi paññā udapādi vijjā
translated: knowledge and vision arose, understanding arose,

original: udapādi, āloko udapādi.
analyzed: udapādi ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: penetration arose, light arose.

original: Yāvakīvañca me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṁ tiparivaṭṭaṁ dvādasākāraṁ🔽yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ na suvisuddhaṁ ahosi, neva tāvāhaṁ, bhikkhave, sadevake
analyzed: yāvakīvat ca me bhikkhave imesu catūsu ariya saccesu evam ti parivaṭṭam dvādasa ākāra  yathābhūtam ñāṇa dassanam na su visuddham ahosi na iva tau āha bhikkhave sa devake
translated: “For as long, bhikkhus, as my knowledge and vision of these four noble truths as they actually are was not thoroughly purified in these three phases and these twelve aspects,

original: loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ🔽abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṁ.
analyzed: loke sa mārake sa brahmake sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya anuttaram sammāsambodhi 🔽abhisambuddhaḥ ti paccaññā asi
translated: then as yet I did not claim to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and hum an beings.🔽But when my knowledge and vision of these four noble truths as they actually are was thoroughly purified in these three phases and these twelve aspects, then I claimed to have awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment in this world with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and human beings.

original: Yato ca kho me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṁ tiparivaṭṭaṁ dvādasākāraṁ🔽yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ suvisuddhaṁ ahosi, athāhaṁ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake
analyzed: yatas ca kho me bhikkhave imesu catūsu ariya saccesu evam ti parivaṭṭam dvādasa ākāra  yathābhūtam ñāṇa dassanam su visuddham ahosi atha āha bhikkhave sa devake loke sa mārake
translated: But when my knowledge and vision became completely purified of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics,🔽then I claimed the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, lords of death,

original: sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṁ.
analyzed: sa brahmake sa samaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ ti paccaññāsi
translated: and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and people.

original: Ñāṇañca pana me dassanaṁ udapādi—
analyzed: ñāṇam ca pana me dassanam udapādi
translated: And knowledge and vision arose in me:

original: akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
analyzed: akuppā me vimutti ayam antimā jāti natthi dāni punabbhavoti
translated: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last birth; now there is no continuation of existence.’

original: Idamavoca bhagavā attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavā attamanā pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: The Buddha said this, and the bhikkhus of the group of five were pleased and they rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words.

original: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne āyasmato koṇḍaññassa virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi—
analyzed: imasmin ca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmataḥ koṇḍaññassa virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum udapādi
translated: And while this discourse was being spoken, there arose to Ven. Koṇḍañña the dust-free, stainless vision of the Dhamma:

original: “yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman”ti.
analyzed: yam kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti
translated: “Whatever is subject to origination is all subject to cessation.”

original: Pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke, bhummā devā saddamanussāvesuṁ—
analyzed: pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke bhummāḥ devāḥ sadda manussāvesu
translated: And when the Dhamma wheel was set rolling by the Blessed One, the devas of the earth cried out:

original: “etaṁ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ, appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
analyzed: etam bhagavatā bārāṇasiyam isipatane migadāye anuttaram dhammacakkam pavattita appaṭivattiyam samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenacid vā lokasmin ti
translated: ‘The Buddha has set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, which cannot be stopped by any ascetic or Brahmin, Mara or Brahma or anyone in the world.’

original: Bhummānaṁ devānaṁ saddaṁ sutvā cātumahārājikā devā saddamanussāvesuṁ …pe…🔽cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ saddaṁ sutvā tāvatiṁsā devā …pe…🔽yāmā devā …pe…🔽tusitā devā …pe…🔽nimmānaratī devā …pe…🔽paranimmitavasavattī devā …pe…
analyzed: bhummānam devānam saddam sutvā cātumahārājikāḥ devā saddam anussāvesum pe  cātumahārājikānam devānam saddam sutvā tāvatisāḥ devāḥ pe  yāmā devā pe  tusitā devā pe  nimmāna ratī devā pe  devā pe
translated: Hearing the cry of the earth gods, the gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings raised a cry:🔽‘The Buddha has set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, which cannot be stopped by any ascetic or Brahmin, Mara or Brahma or anyone in the world.’

original: brahmakāyikā devā saddamanussāvesuṁ—
analyzed: brahmakāyikāḥ devā sadda manussāvesu
translated: The gods of the heaven of the Thirty-three, the Yama gods, the gods of the Tusita heaven, the gods who delight in creating, the gods who wield power over others’ creations, and the Brahma gods all raised a cry:

original: “etaṁ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṁ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitaṁ appaṭivattiyaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
analyzed: etam bhagavatā bārāṇasiyam isipatane migadāye anuttaram dhamma cakkam pavattitam appaṭivattiyam samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenacid vā lokasmin ti
translated: ‘The Buddha has set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, which cannot be stopped by any ascetic or Brahmin, Mara or Brahma or anyone in the world.’

original: Itiha tena khaṇena, tena layena, tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchi.
analyzed: iti ha tena khaṇena tena layena tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā saddaḥ abbhuggacchi
translated: And at that moment, at that instant, at that second, the cry reached as far as the Brahma worlds.

original: Ayañca dasasahassilokadhātu saṅkampi sampakampi sampavedhi;🔽appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pāturahosi, atikkamma devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
analyzed: ayam ca dasa sahassi lokadhātu saṅkampi sampakampi sampavedhi  appamāṇaḥ ca uḷāraḥ obhāsaḥ loke pāturahosi atikkamma devānam deva anubhāva
translated: And this ten-thousandfold world system shook, quivered, and trembled,🔽and an immeasurable, splendid light surpassing the glory of the gods appeared in the world.

original: Atha kho bhagavā imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi—🔽“aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño, aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño”ti.🔽Iti hidaṁ āyasmato koṇḍaññassa “aññāsikoṇḍañño” tveva nāmaṁ ahosi.🔽Atha kho āyasmā aññāsikoṇḍañño diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo🔽tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān imam udānam udānesi  aññā asi vata bho koṇḍañño aññā asi vata bho koṇḍañño ti  iti hi dam āyasmataḥ koṇḍaññassa tu eva nāmam ahosi  atha kho āyasmai aññāsikoṇḍaññaḥ diṭṭha dhammo patta dhammo vidita dhammo pariyogāḷha dhammo  tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ vigata kathaṅkathaḥ vesārajja ppatto apara ppaccayaḥ satthu sāsane bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: And this world system of a billion worlds shook, quivered, and trembled,

original: “labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.🔽“Ehi bhikkhū”ti bhagavā avoca—🔽“svākkhāto dhammo, cara brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.🔽Sāva tassa āyasmato upasampadā ahosi.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti 🔽ehi bhikkhu iti bhagavā avoca 🔽su ākkhātaḥ dhammaḥ cara brahmacariyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati 🔽sā ava tassa āyasmataḥ upasampadā ahosi
translated: and an immeasurable glorious radiance appeared in the world, surpassing the psychic power of the gods.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tadavasese bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tad avasese bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi
translated: The Buddha then instructed and inspired the remaining monks with a teaching.

original: Atha kho āyasmato ca vappassa āyasmato ca bhaddiyassa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānaṁ anusāsiyamānānaṁ virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi—
analyzed: atha kho āyasmataḥ ca vappassa āyasmataḥ ca bhaddiyassa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānam anusāsiyamānānam virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum udapādi
translated: And as the Buddha instructed and inspired them, the dustless and stainless eye of Dhamma arose in them:

original: “yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman”ti.
analyzed: yam kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti
translated: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

original: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: te diṭṭha dhammā patta dhammā vidita dhammā pariyogāḷha dhammā tiṇṇa vicikicchāḥ vigata kathaṅkathāḥ vesārajja ppattāḥ apara paccayā satthu sāsane bhagavantam etat avocu
translated: They had seen the Dhamma, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. They had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,

original: “labheyyāma mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyāma upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyyāma bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyāma upasampadanti
translated: “Sir, may we receive the going forth in the Buddha’s presence? May we receive the full ordination?”

original: “Etha bhikkhavo”ti bhagavā avoca—
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti bhagavā avoca
translated: “Come, monks!” the Buddha said.

original: “svākkhāto dhammo, caratha brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ dhammaḥ caratha brahmacariyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati
translated: “The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”

original: Sāva tesaṁ āyasmantānaṁ upasampadā ahosi.
analyzed: sā ava tesam āyasmantānam upasampadā ahosi
translated: And that was the full ordination of those venerables.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tadavasese bhikkhū nīhārabhatto dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tad avasese bhikkhū nīhāra bhattaḥ dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi
translated: The Buddha then instructed and inspired the remaining monks with a teaching.

original: Yaṁ tayo bhikkhū piṇḍāya caritvā āharanti, tena chabbaggo yāpeti.
analyzed: yam tayaḥ bhikkhū piṇḍāya caritvā āharanti tena chabbaggaḥ yāpeti
translated: The three monks who went for alms brought back enough for all six of them to eat.

original: Atha kho āyasmato ca mahānāmassa āyasmato ca assajissa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānaṁ anusāsiyamānānaṁ virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi—
analyzed: atha kho āyasmataḥ ca mahānāmassa āyasmataḥ ca assajissa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānam anusāsiyamānānam virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum udapādi
translated: Then, while being instructed and inspired by the Buddha, the dustless and stainless eye of Dhamma arose in Mahānāma and Assaji:

original: “yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman”ti.
analyzed: yam kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti
translated: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

original: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: te diṭṭha dhammā patta dhammā vidita dhammā pariyogāḷha dhammā tiṇṇa vicikicchāḥ vigata kathaṅkathāḥ vesārajja ppattāḥ apara paccayā satthu sāsane bhagavantam etat avocu
translated: They had seen the Dhamma, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. They had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,

original: “labheyyāma mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyāma upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyyāma bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyāma upasampadanti
translated: “Sir, may we receive the going forth in the Buddha’s presence? May we receive the full ordination?”

original: “Etha bhikkhavo”ti bhagavā avoca—
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti bhagavā avoca
translated: “Come, monks!” the Buddha said.

original: “svākkhāto dhammo, caratha brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ dhammaḥ caratha brahmacariyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati
translated: “The Dhamma is well-expounded. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”

original: Sāva tesaṁ āyasmantānaṁ upasampadā ahosi.
analyzed: sā ava tesam āyasmantānam upasampadā ahosi
translated: And that was their full ordination.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi—
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: Then the Buddha addressed the group of five monks:

original: “Rūpaṁ, bhikkhave, anattā.
analyzed: rūpa bhikkhave anattā
translated: “Form, monks, is not-self.

original: Rūpañca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ rūpaṁ ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca rūpe—
analyzed: rūpam ca bhikkhave attā abhavissa na yidam rūpam ābādhāya labbhetha ca rūpe
translated: If form were the self, this form would not lead to affliction, and it would be possible to have it of form:

original: ‘evaṁ me rūpaṁ hotu, evaṁ me rūpaṁ mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me rūpam hotu evam me rūpam mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my form be like this, let my form not be like that.’

original: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṁ anattā, tasmā rūpaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati rūpe—
analyzed: yasmā ca kho bhikkhave rūpam anattā tasmā rūpam ābādhāya savattati na ca labbhati rūpe
translated: But precisely because form is not-self, form leads to affliction, and it is not possible to have it of form:

original: ‘evaṁ me rūpaṁ hotu, evaṁ me rūpaṁ mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me rūpam hotu evam me rūpam mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my form be like this, let my form not be like that.’

original: Vedanā anattā.
analyzed: vedanā anattā
translated: Feeling is not-self.

original: Vedanā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ vedanā ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca vedanāya—
analyzed: vedanā ca bhikkhave attā abhavissa na yidam vedanā ābādhāya labbhetha ca vedanāya
translated: If feeling were the self, this feeling would not lead to affliction, and it would be possible to have it of feeling:

original: ‘evaṁ me vedanā hotu, evaṁ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me vedanā hotu evam me vedanā mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my feeling be like this, let my feeling not be like that.’

original: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vedanā anattā, tasmā vedanā ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati vedanāya—
analyzed: yasmā ca kho bhikkhave vedanā anattā tasmā vedanā ābādhāya savattati na ca labbhati vedanāya
translated: But because feelings are not self, they lead to harm. And it’s not possible to say of feelings:

original: ‘evaṁ me vedanā hotu, evaṁ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me vedanā hotu evam me vedanā mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my feelings be like this. Let my feelings not be like that.’

original: Saññā anattā.
analyzed: saññā anattā
translated: Perception is not self.

original: Saññā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ saññā ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca saññāya—
analyzed: saññā ca hida bhikkhave attā abhavissa na yidam saññā ābādhāya labbhetha ca saññāya
translated: If perception were the self, perception would not lead to harm. And it would be possible to say of perception:

original: ‘evaṁ me saññā hotu, evaṁ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me saññā hotu evam me saññā mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my perception be like this. Let my perception not be like that.’

original: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saññā anattā, tasmā saññā ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati saññāya—
analyzed: yasmā ca kho bhikkhave saññā anattā tasmā saññā ābādhāya savattati na ca labbhati saññāya
translated: But because perception is not self, it leads to harm. And it’s not possible to say of perception:

original: ‘evaṁ me saññā hotu, evaṁ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me saññā hotu evam me saññā mā ahosi iti
translated: ‘Let my perception be like this. Let my perception not be like that.’

original: Saṅkhārā anattā.
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ anattā
translated: Thoughts are not self.

original: Saṅkhārā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissaṁsu, nayidaṁ saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṁvatteyyuṁ, labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu—
analyzed: saṅkhārā ca hida bhikkhave attā abhavissasu na yidam saṅkhārāḥ ābādhāya labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu
translated: If thoughts were the self, thoughts would not lead to harm. And it would be possible to say of thoughts:

original: ‘evaṁ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṁ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
analyzed: evam me saṅkhārāḥ hontu evam me saṅkhārāḥ mā ahesunti
translated: ‘Let my thoughts be like this. Let my thoughts not be like that.’

original: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā anattā, tasmā saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṁvattanti, na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu—
analyzed: yasmā ca kho bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ anattā tasmā saṅkhārāḥ ābādhāya savattanti na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu
translated: But because volitional formations are not self, volitional formations lead to affliction. It is not possible to will: ‘Let affliction not come to me.’

original: ‘evaṁ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṁ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
analyzed: evam me saṅkhārāḥ hontu evam me saṅkhārāḥ mā ahesunti
translated: But because volitions are not self, volitions lead to affliction, and it is not the case that one can get volitions to be like this or not be like this.

original: Viññāṇaṁ anattā.
analyzed: viññāṇam anattā
translated: Consciousness is not self.

original: Viññāṇañca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ viññāṇaṁ ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca viññāṇe—🔽‘evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ hotu, evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ mā ahosī’ti.🔽Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe—
analyzed: viññāṇam ca hida bhikkhave attā abhavissa na yidam viññāṇam ābādhāya labbhetha ca viññāṇe  evam me viññāṇam hotu evam me viññāṇam mā ahosi iti  yasmā ca kho bhikkhave viññāṇam anattā tasmā viññāṇam ābādhāya savattati na ca labbhati viññāṇe
translated: If consciousness were the self, consciousness would not lead to affliction, and it would be possible to get consciousness to be like this or not be like this.

original: ‘evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ hotu, evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ mā ahosī’ti.
analyzed: evam me viññāṇam hotu evam me viññāṇam mā ahosi iti
translated: But because consciousness is not self, consciousness leads to affliction, and it is not possible to get consciousness to be like this or not be like this.

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṁ niccaṁ vā aniccaṁ vā”ti?
analyzed: tam kim maññatha bhikkhave rūpam niccam vā aniccam vā ti
translated: “What do you think, bhikkhus, is form permanent or impermanent?”

original: “Aniccaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: an it ca bhante
translated: “Impermanent, venerable sir.”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti?
analyzed: yam pana aniccam dukkham vā tam sukham vā ati
translated: “But if it is impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

original: “Dukkhaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: dukkha bhante
translated: “Suffering, venerable sir.”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ—
analyzed: yam pana aniccam dukkham vipariṇāma dhamma kallam nu tam samanupassitu
translated: “But if it’s impermanent and subject to cessation, is it fitting to regard it thus:

analyzed: etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati
translated: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

analyzed: na itam mama na isaḥ aham asmi na mā isaḥ attā ati

analyzed: evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: This is how things are to be seen with right understanding as they actually are.🔽Whatever feelings there are—whether past, present, or future,

translated: all feelings are not-self.

translated: This is how things are to be seen with right understanding as they actually are.🔽Whatever perceptions there are—whether past, present, or future,

original: Yā kāci saññā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbā saññā—

translated: This is how things are to be seen with right understanding as they actually are.🔽Whatever intentional activities there are—whether past, present, or future,

original: netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
analyzed: na itam mama na isaḥ aham asmi na mā isaḥ attā ati
translated: all intentional activities are not-self.🔽This is how things are to be seen with right understanding as they actually are.

original: evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: This is how things are to be seen with right understanding, as they actually are.

original: Yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ—

translated: Any kind of consciousness whatever, whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having seen all consciousness as it actually is with right understanding thus:

analyzed: na itam mama na isaḥ aham asmi na mā isaḥ attā ati  evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’🔽one turns away from consciousness, detaches the mind from consciousness, and relishes no delight in consciousness.

original: Evaṁ passaṁ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
analyzed: evam passa bhikkhave sutavā ariya sāvakaḥ rūpasmim pi nibbindati vedanāya api nibbindati saññāya api nibbindati saṅkhāresu pi nibbindati viññāṇasmim pi nibbindati
translated: Seeing thus, bhikkhus, the instructed noble disciple experiences revulsion towards form, revulsion towards feeling, revulsion towards perception, revulsion towards volitional formations, revulsion towards consciousness.🔽Experiencing revulsion, he becomes dispassionate.

original: nibbindaṁ virajjati;
analyzed: nibbindam virajjati
translated: Through dispassion his mind is ,

original: virāgā vimuccati;
analyzed: virāgā vimuccati
translated: and he attains liberation.

original: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti khīṇā jāti vusitam brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti iti
translated: When he is liberated, he knows he is liberated, and he understands that birth has been exhausted, the holy life has been fulfilled, the task has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ pañcavaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: Elated, the bhikkhus of the group of five delighted in the Blessed One’s statement.

original: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne pañcavaggiyānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṁsu.
analyzed: imasmin ca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne pañcavaggiyānam bhikkhūnam an upādāya āsavehi cittāni
translated: And as this explanation was being given, the minds of the monks of the group of five were freed from the corruptions through letting go.

original: Tena kho pana samayena cha loke arahanto honti.
analyzed: tena khalu pana samayena cha loke arahantaḥ honti
translated: And at that time there were six perfected ones in the world.

original: Pañcavaggiyakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañcavaggiya kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Group-of-five is finished.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro.
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇavāro
translated: The first section for recitation is finished.

original: 7. Pabbajjākathā
analyzed: pabbajjā kathā
translated: . The Story of the Going-forth
